theme.title: Basic ideas about chords
theme.para: A chord is a set of three or more overlapping notes (sounding at the same time). The chords of three notes are called 'triads', those of four 'tetra chords' ...
Triad chords are formed by superimposing thirds on a note that we call the 'root' note. The second note forms on it a 3rd and the third note forms a 5th.

theme.para: Obviously, any chord can be built on any of the 12 notes of the chromatic scale and, depending on the tonality in which we are, the chord will have the range that expresses its root note: 1st degree (I - tonic); 4th degree (IV - subdominant); 5th degree (V - dominant), etc.

theme.para: Tetra chords are also formed by overlapping thirds, and the fouth note forms a 7th that is dissonant with the root. They are known as 'seventh chords' (which can be major, minor, etc.). The dissonace introduces dynamism and tension in the harmony that tends to resolve over the tonic chord or another chord that does not contain dissonance.
Compare and notice the dissonance between E4 and D5 introduced by the 7th:

theme.para: The most 'powerful' tetra chord is the one whose root note is the V degree. It is known as 'dominant 7th' chord, and it contains a minor seventh.
